hints_html:
Recall that the frequency for

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}e^{2\pi{}inx/L}\end{aligned}\]

is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}\omega=\frac{n}{L}\end{aligned}\]

and that for complex coefficient \(c_n\), the amplitude is the modulus \(\displaystyle {}|c_n|\).
hints_raw:
Recall that the frequency for

:<math>
\displaystyle{}e^{2\pi{}inx/L}
</math>

is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}\omega=\frac{n}{L}
</math>

and that for complex coefficient <math>c_n</math>, the amplitude is the modulus <math>\displaystyle{}|c_n|</math>.
question: 6 (d)
sols_html:
From part (a), we figured out that \(c_{n} = -\frac{1}{2\pi in}\). The modulus of this complex number, \(\left | c_n \right |\), is the amplitude of oscillation with frequency \(\omega _n=n\) since L is equal to 1. We have that

\[\begin{aligned} \left| c_n \right|= \left| -\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right|= \frac1{2\pi n} \left|\frac{-1}{i}\right| = \frac{1}{2\pi n}\end{aligned}\]

for \(n\neq 0\). When \(n = 0\), the amplitude is equal to \(\left| c_0 \right|\) which is \(c_{0} = \frac{1}{2}\) from part (a). Therefore the points for a frequency amplitude plot are \(\displaystyle (n,|c_n|)\) given by

\[\begin{aligned} (0,&1/2)\\ (1,&1/2\pi)\\ (2,&1/4\pi)\\ &\vdots\\ (n,&1/2n\pi)\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
From
{part
(a)}, we figured out that $c_{n} = -\frac{1}{2\pi in}$. The modulus of
this complex number, $\left | c_n \right |$, is the amplitude of
oscillation with frequency $\omega _n=n$ since L is equal to 1. We have
that

\begin{align*}
\left| c_n \right|= \left| -\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right|= \frac1{2\pi n} \left|\frac{-1}{i}\right| = \frac{1}{2\pi n}
\end{align*}

for $n\neq 0$. When $n = 0$, the amplitude is equal to
$\left| c_0 \right|$ which is $c_{0} = \frac{1}{2}$ from
{part
(a)}. Therefore the points for a frequency amplitude plot are
$\displaystyle (n,|c_n|)$ given by

\begin{align*}
(0,&1/2)\\
(1,&1/2\pi)\\
(2,&1/4\pi)\\
&\vdots\\
(n,&1/2n\pi)
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
From [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)|part (a)]], we figured out that <math>c_{n} = -\frac{1}{2\pi in}</math>.  The modulus of this complex number, <math>\left | c_n \right |</math>, is the amplitude of oscillation with frequency <math>\omega _n=n</math> since L is equal to 1.  We have that

:<math>
\left| c_n \right|= \left| -\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right|= \frac1{2\pi n} \left|\frac{-1}{i}\right| = \frac{1}{2\pi n}
</math>

for <math>n\neq 0</math>.  When <math>n = 0</math>, the amplitude is equal to <math>\left| c_0 \right|</math> which is <math>c_{0} = \frac{1}{2}</math> from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)|part (a)]]. Therefore the points for a frequency amplitude plot are <math>\displaystyle(n,|c_n|)</math> given by

:<math>
\begin{align}
(0,&1/2)\\
(1,&1/2\pi)\\
(2,&1/4\pi)\\
&\vdots\\
(n,&1/2n\pi)
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html: What points in the plane would you plot to produce a frequency-amplitude plot for the function in part (a)?
